turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: All the failures, all the fatalism.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: Washed away.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: One more out.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: It's Stanley. It's the Steamer. Fate has spoken to this man in the depths of the night.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: What did it say?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: A thousand things.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: You're hurting my head.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: This could be it!

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: This could be it!

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: Life is true.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Life is real.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I'm at the door.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Go way. I'll call a cop.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Pop, will you let me in?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Where the hell are you?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Right here. At the door.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: It's me. Nicky.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Nicky comes on Sunday's.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Where are your glasses? Go get them.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: If it's you, what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I'm on my way to get a haircut.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Where does Nicky get his hair cut?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Across Ninth Avenue. Dodgie's. Where you've been getting your hair cut for fifty years. Where Uncle Billy and Uncle Marty got their hair cut. Where Jim Rorty shot a man for cheating at poker.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: It was rummy, not poker. But I'll take a chance and let you in.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: It's a constant shock to me, how small this place is. How did we do it? Five people in these little rooms.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Get yourself something to eat.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: We must have been heroic.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Five's not so many. There were families with seven kids. A grandmother. A dimwit uncle.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Lillian says it once a week. `Why doesn't he come live with us?'

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You know the answer to that.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I do know the answer to that. Why don't we watch the ball game later? We'll go to Mannion's.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: They're only gonna lose.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Of course they're gonna lose. We'll watch them lose. What good is heartbreak if we don't experience it firsthand?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: The Red Sox are your problem. I never understood about you and the Red Sox. Everybody rooted for the Yankees.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Remember 1949? Last two games of the season. Against the Yankees. The Sox lost on Saturday. Then they lost on Sunday. First I cried for twenty-four hours. Then I had fist- fights the rest of the week.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: It's one thing for kids. You get older, you Nhave other things.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: It's all connected, Pop. It's one life. Baseball is memory. How do fathers and sons show their love? They go to a ball game together. Thirty-five years later, they sit in the kitchen and remember.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: But the son is suppose to stop crying.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I could have grown up happy. A Yankee fan. A divorce lawyer.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: You'll need these. Tonight. For the play.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Don't make me sit through one of your plays.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Hey, Pop. I know you don't like the commotion of opening night. But I especially want you to see this play. It's new territory for me. And for you too. I have to know what you think.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Since when did that matter?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Let's not start that again.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: My back is killing me.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Where's your elastic brace?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I can't find it.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: You're suppose to wear it when your back gives you trouble.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I lost it. I lose everything.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I'll go get you another one. You have to wear it.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: `Why doesn't he come live with us?' Because everything is here.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I know, Pop.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I'm lucky they don't knock down the building. It could happen anytime. And everything worth remembering is right here.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I think the building's okay. At least for the time being.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You didn't think it was okay when you lived here. You wanted to get out so fast I thought you were running a marathon.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Normal boy's ambition. I like coming back. You know that.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You tell your friends your father used to work the docks. Callused hands. But you had an attitude when you were growing up that wasn't easy for your mother and me to understand.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I was in a hurry to do big things, make big mistakes. Any mistakes were okay as long as it was big. But I'm trying to see these things clearly and honestly. That's the play they're going to kill starting tonight. There's a guy out there getting ready to rip it apart. And that's us. Who we were and where we come from.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: So what are you going to do about it?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: What do you want me to do?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Show him who we are.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: I'm looking at you trying to think. Put your face in the mirror. I know I recognize you from somewhere.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Everybody else does. Why not you?

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: You're Frankie Lazzaro. The gangster from Rhode Island.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Oh yeah?

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: Matthew, look at him. When I lived in Roxbury, the media followed this man everywhere. He was bigger than ten movie stars.  Where's your white Lincoln limo?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Some little kid stole the hubcaps.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: The most charming gangster in New England. Where are we going, Mr. Lazzaro?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Call me Frankie. And it looks like we're going nowhere.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: Might be an accident on the West Side Highway.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: How come you got the kid with you?

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: Matthew's my grandson.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: A grandmother. God bless you.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: He does bless me, each and every day. Matthew's mother works a hospital shift, so I pick him up at school. We stop for a meal usually around this time. He does his homework and gets some experience meeting people. But we never had a famous mobster before.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: It's the kid's lucky day.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: This is one charming crook. If shooting people is charming.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Now that's a complicated subject.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: That's a simple subject.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Look, we're stuck here front and back. It's dinnertime for you, game time for me. Let's park the cab and go to Mannion's. What do you say, Matthew? We'll drink beer and talk baseball.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: You see what you're doing, don't you?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: What am I doing?

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: You're charming the boy.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Hey, Toyota. He asked me a question.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: Frankie Lazzaro. Coming down the courthouse steps every day in the media. Children see this. They think you're the Secretary of the Treasury.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: That's my cousin, Angelo.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: Go on, tell him. Tell the truth. Tell him how you feel, shooting a piece of hot metal in somebody's flesh who was once a child, who was once the same age as this boy. Somebody's flesh who was innocent once.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: It's complicated. It's a whole life. A person doesn't commit an act of violence out of nowhere. There are strong forces at work.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: You're a family man, Frankie?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Wife and daughter. My father's still alive. He outlives me, starting tonight. Because the Mets just tied the score. It was only a matter of time, wasn't it?

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: An how many years does it take a person to make his family safe and secure and happy, and then in one dumb moment, what does he do?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I don't know Toyota. What does he do?

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: And the people he hurts the most are the people who love him. Despite who he is and what he does for a living. We're always saying we want to take control of our lives. You don't want to take control. You want to lose control. Jesus knows it.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: It's a complicated subject.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: It's a simple subject.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: Your problem is you take the easy way out. Losing is easy.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Winning is easy. Losing is complicated. It's a lifetime's work.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: It may be work but it's not honest work. Faith is the real work.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: You made him strike out. You wished it on him. You want to lose. It's too hard for you to believe in something. It's hard to have faith. It's hard Nwork to trust somebody.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: "It looked extremely rocky for the Boston nine that day."

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: You're afraid to risk believing. Believe in them. Believe in your self. Take a risk. It will humanize you as a person.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I want to believe.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: If you believed, you wouldn't be walking around with a handgun in your belt. What does that tell me? You want to make the night come down.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: Say it and you'll believe it. Life is good. Say it.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I want to say it because my whole life may depend on these next few moments.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: Then say it.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Life is good.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: Speak it like it's real. Matthew.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: Matthew.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: This is something no one has been privileged to see in almost seventy years. Very few people now alive can say that they have seen what you are about to see, Matthew. The Red Sox win a World Series. This is deeply, intensely personal. All the mistakes I've made, all the envy, fear and violence that's encased in this little envelope we call a person -- all washed away in the next few minutes. And your grandmother knows why.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: Because God loves a winner.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: He used to love losers. But the laws of physics changed.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: All the times I died when the Red Sox lost an important game they should have won. All the awful things I said to my mother and father. To Tmy wife and daughter.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: Washed away.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Because life is good.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: Because faith is rewarded.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: Don't worry. It's a test.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: It's a test all right. They're bringing in Stanley.

turns.speaker: TOYOTA
turns.text: This could be it!

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: This could be it!

turns.speaker: STEVEN
turns.text: Then they lost?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Why does it matter?

turns.speaker: STEVEN
turns.text: If they lost tonight, they'll lose tomorrow. It's all over.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Why do you care?

turns.speaker: STEVEN
turns.text: They're my team.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: No. They're not your team. They're my team.

turns.speaker: STEVEN
turns.text: They're my team, too. I grew up on Boyleston Street. Right by Fenway Park. I went to fifty or sixty games a year. All by myself. I was one of those kids with scabby elbows. I called out to the players. `Look over here. Hi, I'm Steven. My parents are divorced.'

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I went to college in Boston so I could be near the Red Sox. I took summer classes and the cut them to go to the game. My wife is from Boston. Lillian Ziegler?

turns.speaker: STEVEN
turns.text: The Red Sox were my world. I surrendered my existence to a team that couldn't win the big one.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: If you're such a devoted fan, why were you at the play tonight instead of the game? Answer carefully. This is important. You could have gone to the theater last night. There was no game last night.

turns.speaker: STEVEN
turns.text: Because I can't bear to watch. When they lose, I die inside. It's like some little person named Steve just crumples up and dies. I wait for the scores. I still die, hearing the scores, but it's over in a second. I can't survive the game pitch by pitch, inning by inning. I've done it too many times. And I can't do it anymore.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I was six years old the day Pesky hesitated throwing home and Slaughter scored all the way from first. That's when I knew the Red Sox were my team. Pity and terror.

turns.speaker: STEVEN
turns.text: When I traveled through Asia this summer, I went to tremendous trouble and expense to rent a car with a phone so I could call up Sports Phone in New York and get the scores. I drove through the war in Afghanistan calling Sports Phone like every hour on the hour, for updates.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: What about my play?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: And you're not saying that because of the gun in my hand?

turns.speaker: STEVEN
turns.text: You're out of bullets.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: aybe we ought to postpone the opening.

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: Joanna loves this play. She has sunk tons of money. She is completely Ncommitted.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: appreciate that, Sidney. But our leading man can't remember his lines. And his understudy can't carry the play.

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: I had lunch with Joanna. She said she told you about Peter. You weren't concerned, she said.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: hat was this morning.

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: So what happened since? You're worried about this kid who writes these reviews?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: 'm not worried about this kid.

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: Well I am. Worried sick. Everybody quotes Steven Schwimmer. He's here to announce the death of civilization. He kills a play every time he farts.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Postpone. We have every right.

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: Too late. All the elements are in place. Delay the opening and we lose the theater.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I've had three straight washouts, Sidney.

turns.speaker: SIDNEY
turns.text: You're dangling from the last letter of your last name.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I hate the Mets.

turns.speaker: SECOND MAN
turns.text: How come?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: When the Mets lose, they just lose. It's a flat feeling. But the Red Sox -- here we have a rich history of interesting ways to lose a crucial game. Defeats that keep you awake, that pound in your head like the hammer of fate.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Have to hurry back.

turns.speaker: SECOND MAN
turns.text: Hurry back. Hurry back to what?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Eleventh inning. What else?

turns.speaker: SECOND MAN
turns.text: Game six is history,pal.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: You're not making sense.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: To go to the theater. Wears I don't know what. Make-up, padding.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: Because he is so deeply hated by so many people in the business.

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: Yessiree, Bob.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Get the hell out of here. I don't want you bringing our food. Send a real waiter.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Finally, I get a waiter who doesn't know "Macbeth".

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: But I know you, don't I? I seen you on a poster in the theater district. I'll think of your name in just a --

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Sidney remains optimistic.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Sidney.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Sidney Fabrikant. Our producer.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I was educated by nuns.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I have excellent long-term memory.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I kissed Shirley Felder on the teeth.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Yes, Peter.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: But my parasite is consuming all the new memories. Eating my lines.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: You have to see the words. Try to build a mental picture of the script. Imagine your lines high- lighted with a felt tip pen.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What color?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: What was your favorite color crayon, growing up?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Burnt sienna.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Mine was cobalt blue.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: This is your history, isn't it? Nicky? All around us. And my parasite is consuming it.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I kissed her while she was laughing.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I can see her face so clearly. Dear God. My heart was flying out of my chest with love.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: And the Father replies?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's the line I can't ever, for the life of me remember. I just can't get it.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: This could be it.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I know it sounds easy. But something happens between the time I hear the line and the time I'm suppose to Jrepeat it.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: What's good?

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: We have a very nice pasta today. Alla Putanesca.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: You've worked with Elliot?

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: I was in the fish-market play. What happened to him?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: There was a review.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: I think I remember.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: So does Elliot.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: Not one of Steven's finer moments.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Oh. You know him.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: A little.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: And he has finer moments now and then.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: He has -- something. A funny little quality I find --

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Endearing.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: Engaging.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Elliot wants to kill him with a railroad spike.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: A little drastic maybe?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Say it again.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: You know what.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: Alla puttanesca.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: One more time.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: You keep slipping away. How do you do that?

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: I was one of those silent, listening children. Glued to the shadows.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I was all noise. Played the radio loud. Battled constantly with my brother and sister. Here I am, world.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: I hear good things about the new play.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: So do I. Over and over.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: Peter Redmond is an actor I admire enormously.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Would you like to meet him?

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: He doesn't want to meet some out-of- work ingenue.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I'm trying to prolong our afternoon. In case you haven't noticed.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: The fact is, I have to get going.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Is it true?

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: Is what true?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: He wears a disguise.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: Steven goes to extremes to protect his privacy. No friends. No phone.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: But you're his friend.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: Sort of. Sometimes. You're not building an obsession about Steven, are you? Look. I understand opening- night jitters, but you've got one of the great actors in American theater starring in your play.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: Do you think he can do it?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: He's a very sweet man.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Where are you going now?

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: Home.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Someone waiting for you?

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: No one's waiting.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: There's a certain kind of wounded young man who uses his oddness to get laid. Is that our Steven?

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: If I'm sleeping with him, and I haven't said I am, then so what?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: So everything. That's so what. So I begin to hate him. So I want to do him grave harm.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: But you don't even know me. How can you care what I do with whom?

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I know you both. Enough. How much knowledge does it take before a man does something crazy.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: Do you want to talk about doing crazy things.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: Never mind.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: What? Come on, Paisley.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: Our Steven not only disguises himself.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: He goes to the theater armed.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: He feels he has to defend himself if necessary.

turns.speaker: NICKY
turns.text: I'm actually beginning to enjoy this.

turns.speaker: STEVEN
turns.text: You've come to me. I wanted to believe you would one day.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: I haven't come to you.

turns.speaker: STEVEN
turns.text: But you're here. So you must have come to me.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: In other words I never understood until today how much pain and anxiety you've been causing with your reviews. Steven, it's so unfair.

turns.speaker: STEVEN
turns.text: Of course it's unfair. The truth is always unfair. Why do you think I live this way? Hiding out. Stealing electricity from a lamp post. Because people who write the truth are outcasts of society. I can't live openly, in a nice clean doorman building, with my name on the mailbox. They'd come after me in packs.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: Not if you stopped hurting people. Write the truth gently.

turns.speaker: STEVEN
turns.text: The truth is never gentle. Listen to me carefully. Each of us lives in the thinnest possible wrapping of wishes and dreams. Truth is the force that penetrates this wispy skin. It hurts and maims.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: Yes. I've seen your victims. One past and one future. I thought I might convince you to reconsider.

turns.speaker: STEVEN
turns.text: And I thought, at last, she's here, she wants me.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: I don't want you, Steven.

turns.speaker: STEVEN
turns.text: Stay. Teach me to be compassionate.

turns.speaker: PAISLEY
turns.text: I'm going home to my machine.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: "A high court judge has confirmed that Mr. Gandhi would have been within his rights to prosecute for assault since neither he nor Mr. Khan resisted arrest." -- I told you about English law.

turns.speaker: BA
turns.text: As I told you about English policemen.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Just like proper English gentlemen. I'm proud of them.

turns.speaker: BA
turns.text: They are boys. -- And they're Indian.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Here, you see? Even the South African papers apologize -- "a monstrous attack."

turns.speaker: BA
turns.text: Are you sure?

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Yes -- I can't talk like this.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Oww!

turns.speaker: BA
turns.text: Mr. Khan said they called you brave.

turns.speaker: BA
turns.text: Sora was sent to tell me I -- I must rake and cover the latrine.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Everyone takes his turn.

turns.speaker: BA
turns.text: It is the work of untouchables.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: In this place there are no untouchables -- and no work is beneath any of us!

turns.speaker: BA
turns.text: I am your wife.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: All the more reason.

turns.speaker: BA
turns.text: Please! You're being foolish!

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: There's no room! And the air is lovely.

turns.speaker: BA
turns.text: God gave you ten thumbs.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Eleven.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: "Take a fifth step, that we may serve the people."

turns.speaker: BA
turns.text: "I will follow close behind you and help to serve the people."

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: "Take a sixth step, that we may follow our vows in life."

turns.speaker: BA
turns.text: "I will follow you in all our vows and duties."

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: No -- prison is rather agreeable to me, and there is no doubt that after the war, independence will come. My only worry is what shape it will take. Jinnah has --

turns.speaker: BOURKE-WHITE
turns.text: Stop!

turns.speaker: BOURKE-WHITE
turns.text: "...what shape it will take." Jinnah has -- what?

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Jinnah has -- has cooperated with the British. It has given him power and the freedom to speak, and he has filled the Muslims with fears of what will happen to them in a country that is predominantly Hindu.  That I find hard to bear -- even in prison.

turns.speaker: BOURKE-WHITE
turns.text: But do you really believe you could use non-violence against someone like Hitler?

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Not without defeats -- and great pain.  But are there no defeats in this war -- no pain?  What you cannot do is accept injustice. From Hitler -- or anyone. You must make the injustice visible -- be prepared to die like a soldier to do so.

turns.speaker: BOURKE-WHITE
turns.text: Is my finger supposed to be wrapped around that?

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: No. That is what you get for distracting me.

turns.speaker: BOURKE-WHITE
turns.text: What do you expect when you talk like that?

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: I expect you to show as much patience as I am now.

turns.speaker: BOURKE-WHITE
turns.text: You really are going to Pakistan, then?  You are a stubborn man.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: I'm simply going to prove to Muslims there, and Hindus here, that the only devils in the world are those running around in our own hearts -- and that's where all our battles ought to be fought.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Enough.

turns.speaker: BOURKE-WHITE
turns.text: One more.

turns.speaker: BOURKE-WHITE
turns.text: Just an admirer...

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Nothing's more dangerous, especially for an old man.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You'd be Gandhi --  ...I thought you'd be bigger.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I -- I mean it's all right. It doesn't matter.  I'm -- my name is Andrews, Charlie Andrews. I've come from India -- I've read a great deal about you.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Some of it good, I hope.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: You're a clergyman.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yes. I've -- I've met some very remarkable people in India... and -- and when I read what you've been doing here, I -- I wanted to help.  Does that surprise you?

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Not anymore.  At first I was amazed... but when you are fighting in a just cause, people seem to pop up -- like you -- right out of the pavement. Even when it is dangerous or --

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: That was lucky.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: I thought you were a man of God.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I am. But I'm not so egotistical as to think He plans His day around my dilemmas.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: That's the sort of thing you'll be seeking on this "farm"...

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Well, we shall try.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: No violence, please.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Let me hang on with two hands or I will fall.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Going nearer to God!

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Not quite. They're only "holding me" until the Magistrate's hearing. Then it will be prison.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Did they take your clothes?

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: If I want to be one with them, I have to live like them.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I think you do.  But I thank God we all don't.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: I'm sure your legs are quite as handsome as mine.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Ah, but my puritanism runs the another way. I'm far too modest for such a display.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: They're calling you "Bapu." I thought it meant father.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: It does. We must be getting old, Charlie.

turns.speaker: WALKER
turns.text: ...and I knew something had to give. And I was determined to be here when it did.

turns.speaker: COLLINS
turns.text: How does a reporter in Central America learn that Gandhi was born in Porbandar anyway?

turns.speaker: WALKER
turns.text: Oh, I've been a Gandhi buff for a long time.

turns.speaker: COLLINS
turns.text: You mean Gandhi?

turns.speaker: WALKER
turns.text: Back in South Africa...  long time ago.

turns.speaker: COLLINS
turns.text: What was he like?

turns.speaker: WALKER
turns.text: Lots of hair... and a little like a college freshman -- trying to figure everything out.

turns.speaker: COLLINS
turns.text: Well, he must've found some of the answers...

turns.speaker: COLLINS
turns.text: What'd he say?

turns.speaker: WALKER
turns.text: He said he's in charge...

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Tell me -- do you think about hell?

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: "Hell!"

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: No -- neither do I. But...  but this man is a Christian and he has written --

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: Excuse me, baas, but how long have you been in South Africa?

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: A -- a week.

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: Well, I don't know how you got a ticket for --

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: I'll take your luggage back, baas.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: No, no -- just a moment, please.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: We only make wild speeches, or perform even wilder acts of terrorism. We've bred an army of anarchists but not one single group that can really fight the British anywhere.

turns.speaker: NEHRU
turns.text: I thought you were against fighting.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Fortunately such news comes very slowly where I live.

turns.speaker: NEHRU
turns.text: I think if we all worked to publicize it... all of the Congress... every avenue we know.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Maybe I'm wrong... maybe we're not ready yet. In South Africa the numbers were small...

turns.speaker: NEHRU
turns.text: The Government's afraid, and they don't know what to do. But they're more afraid of terrorists than of you. The Viceroy has agreed to your release if you will speak for non- violence.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: I've never spoken for anything else.

turns.speaker: NEHRU
turns.text: What can we do?

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: We must end the campaign.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: If we obtain our freedom by murder and bloodshed I want no part of it.

turns.speaker: NEHRU
turns.text: It was one incident.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Tell that to the families of the policemen who died.

turns.speaker: NEHRU
turns.text: I don't believe it -- even the British can't be that stupid!

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Panditji -- please, help me.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: And Jinnah?

turns.speaker: NEHRU
turns.text: He's waiting. He's not prepared to accept it will mean as much as you think.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Wait and see... wait and see...

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: They are only clinging to old dreams  and trying to split us in the old way. But the will has gone -- Independence will drop like a ripe apple. The only question is when  and how.

turns.speaker: NEHRU
turns.text: I say when is now -- and we will determine how.

turns.speaker: NEHRU
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: That the fighting will stop -- that you make me believe it will never start again.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Without a paper -- a journal of some kind -- you cannot unite a community.  You belong to a very important profession.

turns.speaker: WALKER
turns.text: Hm. And what should an "important professional" write about your response to General Smuts's new legislation?

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: I don't know... I'm still searching for a "response."

turns.speaker: WALKER
turns.text: You will respect the law.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: There are unjust laws -- as there are unjust men.

turns.speaker: WALKER
turns.text: Well, it's quite a place, your "ashram" -- is that right?

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: That's right. The word only means "community." But it could stand for "village"... or the world.

turns.speaker: WALKER
turns.text: You're an ambitious man.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: I hope not.

turns.speaker: WALKER
turns.text: It's beautiful.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Even as a boy I thought so.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: And you've come all this way because you think something is going to happen?

turns.speaker: WALKER
turns.text: Hm.  Is it?

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Perhaps. I've come here to think about it.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: Do you remember much of South Africa?

turns.speaker: WALKER
turns.text: A great deal.

turns.speaker: GANDHI
turns.text: I've traveled so far -- and thought so much.  As you can see, my city was a sea city -- always filled with Hindus and Muslims and Sikhs and Jews and Persians.  The temple where you were yesterday is of my family's sect, the Pranami. It was Hindu of course but the priests used to read from the Muslim Koran and the Hindu Gita, moving from one to the other as though it mattered not at all which book was read as long as God was worshipped.
